_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Sun Chemical Corporation

Bushy Park Facility

1506 Bushy Park Road

Goose Creek, SC 29445



I. FACILITY INFORMATION

Sun Chemical Corporation's Bushy Park Facility manufactures various types of high performance organic color pigments used in the plastic, paints, and coatings industry.  The Sun Chemical Corporation Divisional headquarters is located in Cincinnati, Ohio.  This Sun Chemical Corporation facility was formerly owned and operated by Bayer Corporation, who established the Bushy Park site in 1970.  This facility was acquired by Sun Chemical Corporation in February 2003.  Before this filing date, Sun Chemical Corporation holdings at the Bushy Park Industrial Complex were included in the Risk Management Plan (RMP) of Bayer Corporation, who filed their RMP by the statutory deadline.  This Sun Chemical Corporation facility is located within the Bushy Park Industrial Complex's 1650-acre site, which is owned (the land) by Cooper River Partners (CRP), LTD.  Various tenants and their asses are located on-site.  The site is on the Cooper River, just a few miles east of Goose Creek, South Carolina. 



II. ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION & EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES



Sun Chemical is committed to health, safety, and the environment.  Sun Chemical considers its responsibility to protect the environment and the health and safety of its employees, customers, and the area communities of primary importance in the conduct of its business.  It is Sun Chemical's policy to comply with all applicable laws and regulations and to establish and implement responsible practices where laws and regulations do not exist.  Further, Sun Chemical will work with government and industry groups to foster the development of appropriate health, safety, and environmental programs, laws, and regulations. Sun Chemical will communicate with its employees, customers, suppliers, communities, and the public to recognize and respond to their concerns and to improve their understanding of the health,

safety, and environmental considerations related to Sun Chemical's operations and products.  Sun Chemical is committed to continually improving health, safety, and environmental performance.



Our industry creates products and services that make life better for many people around the world - both today and tomorrow.  We will make continuous progress toward the goal of no accidents, injuries, or harm to the environment.  We will adhere to the following principals:



> To provide pigments that can be manufactured, transported, used, and disposed of safely.

> To make health, safety, the environment and resource conservation critical considerations for all new and existing products and processes.

> To provide information on health or environmental risks and pursue protective measures for employees, the public, and other important stakeholders.

> To work with customers, carriers, suppliers, distributors, and contractors to foster the safe use, transport, and disposal of pigments.

> To operate our facilities in a manner that protects the environment and the health and safety of our employees and the public.

> To support education and research on the health, safety and environmental effects of our products and processes.

> To work with others to resolve problems created by past handling and disposal practices.



Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC):



Sun Chemical will work with the county and local agencies and response groups to provide information about the chemicals we use on our site.  In addition, the site emergency plans have been integrated with the emergency plans of the county and local fire departments through the LanXess Industrial Park Emergency Management function that operates for the benefit of the entire site.

 

Compliance and Commitment to Safety:



Protection of our employees and neighbors is our highest priority, and that is why we have installed multiple safeguards to ensure that all chemicals are handled safely.  We also work closel

y with our suppliers, other companies, local officials, and the public to maintain stringent safety and environmental programs and to minimize risks.  



In keeping with our commitment, Sun Chemical has developed a Risk Management Plan (RMP) in compliance with guidelines established by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA).  Under EPA guidelines, facilities that handle certain quantities of regulated chemicals must submit plans that show the consequences of hypothetical chemical releases.  Facilities must also outline their measures to reduce the risk of releases and minimize their effects.



Several processes at the site are regulated by the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) requirements listed in 29 CFR Part 1910.119.  PSM and RMP complement each other in that PSM is concerned about the facility employees and RMP is concerned about the public and the environment.  Sun Chemical at the Bushy Park site is in full compliance with PSM requirements.  



III. RMP REGULATED SUBSTANCES



Sun Chemical uses anhydrous ammonia as a refrigerant in process areas.  Previously, these areas were included in the Bayer RMP for anhydrous ammonia.  Anhydrous ammonia is delivered via an overhead pipeline system from the CRP plant-wide distribution system.  Sun Chemical also uses chiller systems to provide anhydrous ammonia as a refrigerant in Building sC8-2 and C9-2.  This system contains anhydrous ammonia below the regulated quantity.  It has a backup supply connection to the CRP's operated site-wide anhydrous ammonia system in the event of a refrigeration unit failure.  Anhydrous ammonia when released to the atmosphere is a colorless gas with a strong pungent odor.  Exposure to anhydrous ammonia can irritate the eyes, nose and throat.  Exposure to extremely high levels can result in a buildup of fluid in the lungs and can be life threatening.



Sun Chemical will also continue to use methyl chloride to make an intermediate product in the manufacture of paint pigments i

n building C8-1.  Methyl chloride when released to the atmosphere is a clear flammable gas with a sweet ether-like odor.  It is extremely flammable in the liquid and vapor state with an OSHA PEL of 100 PPM.  Inhalation is the primary potential route of exposure that causes depression of the central nervous system possibly leading to headache, nausea, vomiting, drowsiness, dizziness, diarrhea, and blurred vision.  Severe or prolonged exposure can cause serious consequences and can be life threatening.



Sun Chemical also uses 20% Oleum in three separate processes.  Oleum is used in one process in Building C8-2 to produce a pigment product #R6422.  The Oleum is mixed with 96% sulfuric acid to raise the strength of the acid to 98%.  Pigment powder is then dissolved into this mixture.  Oleum is also used in two separate processes in Building C9-1.  Building C9-1 is owned by Kemira Corporation.  Kemira uses the oleum to produce two pigment crude acid pasting products.  In both products the oleum is mixed with 95% sulfuric acid to raise the concentration of the acid mixture to 97.5%.  The pigment crude powder is dissolved into this mixture.  The Oleum is pumped from the top of the tank directly from the bulk storage tank to the reaction vessels.  Flow rates, pounds charged, reactor levels, and temperatures are all monitored during the process.  Offloading is also continuously monitored.  The bulk storage tank pressure, temperature, and level are monitored.  The most likely point of failure would be a flange leak at the top of the tank, and maintenance does regular inspections on the header piping.



IV. RELEASE SCENARIOS



A worst case scenario and an alternative case scenario (or more likely scenario) is included in the RMP for each of the three regulated substances.  



Worst Case Scenarios



The anhydrous ammonia worst-case scenario is based on the complete failure of the largest process vessel in the system containing 36,200 pounds of liquid anhydrous ammonia.  A

written operating procedure, high level alarm, and visual level display in the CRP's control room prevent the vessel from being operated with more than 36,200 pounds of liquid anhydrous ammonia.  The maximum distance for the most impacting hypothetical worst case release with no mitigating measures is 3.6 miles to the toxic endpoint.  Several industrial, commercial, residential, public, and military facilities are in the potential impact area.



The methyl chloride worst-case scenario is based on the complete failure of the two storage tanks containing 56,500 pounds of liquid methyl chloride.  The maximum distance for the most impacting hypothetical worst case release with no mitigating measures is 2.1 miles to the toxic endpoint.  Several industrial, commercial, residential, public, and military facilities are in the potential impact area.



The oleum worst-case scenario is based on the complete failure of the storage tank with a maximum capacity of 167,000 pounds of liquid oleum.  The maximum distance for the most impacting hypothetical worst case release, with a dike for mitigation measure, is 0.4 miles to the toxic endpoint.  The on-site industrial facilities are in the potential impact area.



Toxic Endpoints



The Emergency Response Planning Guideline 2 (ERPG2) is the maximum airborne concentration below which it is believed that nearly all individuals can be exposed for up to one hour without experiencing or developing irreversible or serious health effects, or symptoms which impair their ability to take protective action.  The release impact distance is the distance downwind to the ERPG2 concentration.  The ERPG2 for anhydrous ammonia is 0.14 mg/L.  The ERPG2 for methyl chloride is 0.82 mg/L.  The ERPG2 for oleum is 0.01 mg/L.



All scenarios evaluated used the EPA's RMP*Comp model to provide toxic endpoint determinations, based on EPA-published levels of concern (LOC).  Also, the substances were each evaluated for an alternate scenario.  



Alternate

Scenarios



Anhydrous ammonia, methyl chloride, and oleum process systems are similar in function.  Each has a storage container or containers and a transfer system, which includes transfer pump(s) and piping to deliver the material to an end use function.  The more likely scenario for each could involve a breach in the integrity of the piping system or operator error.  A flange leak or rupture could constitute a likely potential for a release of the regulated substance.  The ammonia piping system is constructed with welded pipe where a leak could not occur.  Flanged connections are used for pumps, vessel attachment and critical control valves so they can be taken out easily when repair or replacement is necessary.  



The methyl chloride and oleum piping system is similar.  The opportunity for leaks and/or ruptures is also reduced. The methyl chloride and oleum systems were part of the acquisition.  No accidents occurred before Sun Chemical to use as a history for handling.  Similar systems in operation were included in the review.



The alternative scenario is a hypothetical release that is more realistic than the worst-case scenario.  In this scenario, safety and emergency systems operate as expected, and plant personnel respond to act to control and stop the release.



Anhydrous Ammonia Alternate Scenario Assumptions



> Partial failure of the piping system containing ammonia gas under pressure. 

> Detection of anhydrous ammonia by instruments or personnel in the area, shutdown of the anhydrous ammonia supply equipment by remote control, and closure of valves by site personnel to stop the leak.

> Release during typical weather conditions experienced at the site.



The alternative release scenario for anhydrous ammonia is based on the improper positioning of a block valve assembly during routine maintenance.  A valve opening that was expected to be free of gaseous ammonia instead would still be pressurized.  Gaseous ammonia would be released at 596 pound

s per minute.  The time to discovery and system shut down is based on a 10-minute event.  The distance to the toxic end-point is estimated to be 0.1 miles using RMP*Comp.  Mitigation measures included release in enclosed space, in direct contact with outside air.  The impact area is within the Bushy Park fence line / property line.



Methyl Chloride Alternate Scenario Assumptions:



> Partial failure of a pipe containing methyl chloride under pressure.

> Detection of methyl chloride from instruments in the area or operations personnel, shutdown of the methyl chloride supply equipment by remote control, and closure of valves by operations personnel to stop the leak.

> Release during typical weather conditions experienced at the site.



The alternative release scenario for methyl chloride is based on a 1/4-inch diameter hole in a flange gasket of a transfer pipe that would release 63 pounds per minute of methyl chloride gas.  The time to discovery and system shut down is based on a 15-minute release.  The distance to the toxic end-point is estimated to be 0.1 miles using RMP*Comp.  Mitigation measures included release in enclosed space, in direct contact with outside air.  The impact area is within the Bushy Park fence line / property line.



Oleum Alternate Release Scenario Assumption



> Partial failure of a pipe or flange under pressure in oleum service

> Detection of release by personnel in the area or from the monitoring devices that detect the weight loss in the storage tank and the respective weight addition into the receiving tank

> Release during typical weather conditions for the site



The alternate release scenario for oleum is not required for Program 1 chemicals; however the following could be the scenario for an alternative release.  Based on a leaking valve or valve not fully closed, it is assumed that it would take up to 5 minutes for the release to be detected either by personnel in the area or by the monitoring equipment that is monitoring

the transfer of the oleum.  This equates to a release of 75 pounds.  The distance to the toxic endpoint using RMP*Comp is 0.1 miles, with a dike mitigation measure included.  The impact area is within the Bushy Park fence line / property line.



V. FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



During the past five years, Sun Chemical did not experience any accidental release of anhydrous ammonia, methyl chloride, or oleum.



VI. EMERGENCY RESPONSE



Incident and Emergency Guidelines



Sun Chemical has multiple safeguards in place to ensure safe handling of the RMP regulated chemicals to prevent releases of these substances.  Our facility is prepared to handle emergencies such as hurricanes and tornadoes as well as chemical releases.  In the unlikely event a release occurs, we work to contain the release quickly and to minimize its impact on plant personnel and neighbors.  If a release occurs, equipment that supplies the regulated substance would be shut down quickly by remote control.



Sun Chemical is a partner and participates in the Bushy Park Industrial Complex's Emergency Operations Center (EOC) that CRP manages.  If a release occurs, the EOC is activated and the follow actions are implemented:



> The plant alarm would be sounded and the emergency communicated to plant personnel over the site wide emergency alert system.

> Trained on-site emergency response teams would be activated and take prompt action to control and stop the release. 

> Emergency response personnel would evaluate the extent and impact of the release

> If the release would have potential off-site impact, or outside assistance needed, local and county emergency response personnel would be notified and activated.

> Neighbors in the immediate area that might be affected would be notified and advised to take appropriate action.

> If necessary, site specialists would be activated to perform computer modeling to estimate the area affected by the release. 

> If needed, the site has immediate access to

emergency resources and assistance from its corporate headquarters.



Training and Preparation



Sun Chemical trains employees on the safe handling of anhydrous ammonia, methyl chloride, and oleum and how to respond appropriately, if a release occurs.  Some examples of our preparation and training include:



> Written procedures to handle all types of emergencies.

> Regularly scheduled safety training for operators and maintenance personnel responsible for the regulated substance system.



As part of the EOC, Sun Chemical also participates in various Bushy Park Industrial Complex Emergency Services program that CRP manages.  These programs include the following:



> Trained and experienced on-site emergency response teams (Fire & Rescue, EMTs, and Hazmat).

> Emergency planning with the local fire department and county emergency preparedness personnel.

> Planning and training with the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) and participation in annual drills.

> Routine testing of plant-wide emergency response, alerting, and communications systems.

> Fully equipped emergency response vehicles (fire truck, ambulance, and hazmat truck).

> Emergency response personnel trained annually at nationally recognized schools.

> Certified Hazmat Team to respond to off-site transportation and distribution incidents.



VII. RELEASE PREVENTION AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION 



Assuring Safe Operations



Sun Chemical has programs and activities to ensure safe operation of its anhydrous ammonia, methyl chloride, and oleum handling systems.  Some examples include:



> Production and maintenance personnel are trained in the safe operation and repair of the system.

> Written operating and maintenance procedures are in place and updated regularly.

> Qualified personnel conduct full in-depth hazard and operability studies at least every 5 years.

> Complete safety reviews are conducted before making any changes to the operation or equipment.

> Health, environmental,

and safety audits are conducted at least every 3 years to ensure compliance with regulations.

> Maintenance work is planned ahead of time and work permits issued to assure work is performed safely.

> Regular inspections of equipment, instruments, and piping are conducted to assure integrity of the system.

> Scheduled preventive maintenance work is performed to assure equipment is safe, reliable, and efficient.

> All incidents are investigated and actions are taken to prevent recurrence.



Designing for Safety



Sun Chemical has installed multiple safeguards and systems to reduce the likelihood of anhydrous ammonia, methyl chloride, and oleum incidents, including:



> Piping systems where applicable are all welded construction outside of containment areas.

> The systems are equipped with instrumentation that controls each operation within safe limits.

> Emergency shutdown systems are installed to immediately isolate each system and minimize upsets.

> Operating personnel monitor each system regularly to identify any potential problems.



VIII. IMPROVING SAFETY PERFORMANCE



Sun Chemical has an ongoing commitment to safety.  Sun Chemical uses a structured approach to safety management that relies strongly on the participation of all employees and insures communication of safety related information at all levels of the plant.  In addition, Sun Chemical's Continuous Improvement Program and ISO-9000 process include safety performance and improvement on an equal basis with quality and productivity.



Sun Chemical management encourages all of the Continuous Improvement teams to review and evaluate operations and recommend safety, environmental, and operational improvements.  This philosophy applies to our entire facility and continues to expand its scope to include operations in the new plant. Efforts in various areas of the Bushy Park plant have resulted in projects like:



> Certification of the Sun Chemical - Bushy Park facility in the "SunCare" program.

SunCare is an EHS program for Sun Chemical Corporation.  SunCare has several significant aspects:  OSHA Incident Rate (OIR) <2.0, completion of two significant EHS projects per year, compliance with all regulations (including proper documentation), completion of safety and environmental aspect ratings for plant site, 5S programs, and completion of a regulatory audit (scoring better than 70% in all categories).  It also involves the use of 6-sigma and the Continuous Improvement Process (CIP).  When all of the aspects are achieved, the facility becomes SunCare Certified.  The 5S program is a part of the operational culture of the Sun Chemical Bushy Park plant site.  5S is a productivity improvement program that involves workspace, cleanliness, product flow, etc.  The 5Ss are:  Sort, Set in Order, Shine, Standardize, and Sustain.
